captions.text: Hey what's up everybody,
I'm Rob, Welcome to Man Vs. Pin
The show where you find something cool on Pinterest and send it to us and then we try to remake it
without failing miserably,
After last week's mildly successful attempt to recreate a $4100 forest shadow chandelier
Karichi commented asking if I would consider doing a Tea Cup Lamp she saw from this pin
I've been itching to do a desk lamp project, so I thought this one would be awesome
I am not a certified electrician so neither ThreadBanger or YouTube will be responsible for your house burning down to a fiery pile of ashes
With that said, let's get started
First things first, we're headed over to the thrift store and headed to the lamp section
Here you'll find a plethora of lighting options. You wanna look for something similar to this desk lamp or
Or a downward facing lamp that's easy to take apart and rewire
Here's a tip, IKEA lamps aren't built to be taken apart, so leave those suckers behind
Next, head on over to the dishware department and pick yourself up some decorative china
There wasn't a lot to choose from here, and I'm sure if you spend some time looking you could
Find better, but I thought this plate and teacup combination was kinda cool, especially with the gray lamp
I picked up both sets, anticipating to at least *Bleep* up half of them.
Total: $6
Next, stop at the hardware store and get yourself a circular, diamond tipped drill bit
This is what you need to to properly drill through china
This one is 3/4 on an inch and probably the most expensive item you're gonna need to buy.
At a whopping $23
I read somewhere that you can get away with a ceramic tile bit that cost's half as much, but there's a greater chance of breakage
So, *Bleep* all that
While you're there, pick yourself up an electrical cord along with a small light bulb socket
This one is 3/4 on an inch, put's out 7 1/2 Watts and takes a smaller bulb, similar to that of a night light
You'll need one of those bulbs too if you don't already have one
Other materials you'll need: Some super glue, an electric drill, and a couple of other random tools like screwdrivers
pliers, and scissors
Alright, let's just go straight into the hard stuff and start drilling some tea cups
First you're gonna put down s small, damp washcloth to set your teacup on top of
This will prevent it from sliding all over the place
Then, add a small amount of water to the bottom of your teacup till it forms a small pool
This helps keep the bit cool and supplies the friction the bit needs to drill smoothly
Throw on some safety goggles, and then roughly find where the center of the teacup is with your drill
And with the drill bit at an angle, you're gonna create a small groove on the bottom
It'll take a second of sliding around a bit to grab on, so give it a moment to catch while adding a small amount of pressure
It'll look something like this
Now the motion you want to follow is that of drilling at an angle to drilling straight down
Again, just take it slow and remember to apple a small to medium amount of pressure
You'll feel whats right and whats working
It takes about two or three minutes I'd say to slowly make your way through
Be sure to check your progress every so often, making sure to reapply the small bit of water each time
You'll feel the ceramic give a bit, it's at this time you'll apply minimal pressure and make sure that your
drill bit doesn't slip through the whole thing and break your cup
Once it's all the way through. celebrate! You didn't break anything.
You'll now apply the small exact instructions to the plate
Find the center, apply water, create a small divot, slowly drill through, and celebrate
You didn't *BLEEP* that one up either
Next, just apply some glue to the bottom of the tea cup, align the holes and
place down on top of your place
While that's drying, it's time to get started on the lamp
First off, make sure that everything is unplugged
Now all you really want from this lamp is the base and the stem
So gut everything else by unscrewing, cutting, dismantling, and removing all electrical elements and other pieces
The electrical cord that you got should have an exposed end with the wires sticking out like so
Just run that up the bottom of the lamp 'till it comes out the top
While at the hardware store, I picked up this small, white PVC pipe adapter that I'm going to use
as the enclosure to the back of the lamp
For now, I'm just sliding that down the bottom
Neck, take your socket and unscrew the two metal screws on either side
It'll look a little like Frankenstein once you're done
Then, feed your wire through the bottom of the socket, and attack one wire to either side
By simply wrapping the wire around the base of the screw then tightening back up with your screwdriver
Reapply the cardboard cover, screw your socket onto your lamp, and then throw your bulb in to test it all out
Sweet, it works
Now take the bulb back out and carefully apply your tea cup and saucer combo
Your socket should snugly slide in like so
Using some more super glue, add some to the back of your PVC enclosure and apply to the back of your tea cup
I also added some to the inside of the tea cup around the light socket to further secure it in place
Once everything was dried I put back in the light bulb, plugged it in
And you've got yourself a Tea Cup Desk Lamp
My friends, which, I might add, looks pretty awesome
I'm actually pretty impressed
Grand total for this project came out to be $38
Again, with the biggest expense being the $23 drill bit, which I plan on using this eventually for more projects so
It's gonna be worth it for me in the long run
Got a pin you want me to try out, leave it in the comments below, and we just might give it a shot
Be sure to like this video, it's right other there, somewhere
Subscribe, and we'll see you next time

title: DIY Tea Cup Lamp - MAN VS PIN #2
